title: Baby humpback whale trapped in shark nets rescued off Sydney's Northern Beaches
text:
A baby humpback whale has been freed from shark netting in a miraculous rescue operation.

The whale was entangled in the ropes and buoys for several days before it was finally freed in Manly, on Sydney's Northern Beaches, on Friday morning.

The young calf was exhausted and distressed as its mother swam alongside anxiously, as rescue teams worked tirelessly to cut it loose.

The whale is believed to have been trapped in the ropes since travelling from Queensland on its way down to Antarctica.

Rescue crews from the National Parks and Wildlife Service, as well as the New South Wales Water Police, spent more than an hour trying to cut the whale free.

The Organisation for the Rescue and Research of Cetaceans in Australia (ORRCA) had been notified of the entangled whale on Sunday and it was again seen floundering near the Central Coast on Thursday.

'It's great to see the young whale free to be able to continue its journey south with its mother, and there is every reason to think it will be making many more,' Environment Minister Matt Kean said in a statement.

'The operation was completed as a protective mother hovered anxiously nearby.'

'Using a small inflatable boat, supported by a larger safety vessel, a crew of three cut the material in a delicate operation lasting about an hour. A small amount of remaining material is expected to dislodge over coming days,' he said.

The whale is believed to have been trapped in the ropes since travelling from Queensland on its way down to Antarctica (pictured)

Rescue teams managed to free the whale after spending an hour cutting the ropes and netting (pictured)

The whale was believed to be caught in netting from the Queensland Shark Control Program.

But Jacqueline O'Neill, president of the Organisation for the Rescue and Research of Cetaceans in Australia believes shark nets aren't always beneficial.

'We, as an organisation, do believe there are more effective ways to make swimmer feel comfortable,' Ms O'Neill told The Sydney Morning Herald.

'The less whales that can be caught the better.'

If the whale hadn't been freed from the nets, experts believed it would become so exhausted that it would have died before reaching Antarctica.

Authorities said some of the rope is still wrapped around the whale's body and they will continue to monitor it on its journey south.
description: The whale had been entangled in the ropes and buoys for a several days before it was finally freed on Friday morning in Manly, on Sydney's Northern Beaches.
authors: Eliza Mcphee For Daily Mail Australia
